natural problem: Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins?
natural solution: Alex wants to minimize the number of coins he gives to his friends without giving any two of them the same number of coins. The minimum number of coins he can give to a friend is 1. He then gives 2 coins to another friend, then 3 to another, then 4, and so on, until the last friend receives 12.
The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "additional_coins = 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> friends \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!m. m \<ge> n \<and> m \<le> coins + additional_coins \<and> (\<forall>k. k \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> m \<noteq> k)))"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Alex wants to minimize the number of coins he gives to his friends without giving any two of them the same number of coins. The minimum number of coins he can give to a friend is 1. He then gives 2 coins to another friend, then 3 to another, then 4, and so on, until the last friend receives 12.
 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "additional_coins = 15 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> friends \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>!m. m \<ge> n \<and> m \<le> coins + additional_coins \<and> (\<forall>k. k \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> m \<noteq> k)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 12 friends and 63 coins initially. If 15 additional coins are added, can every friend get a unique number of coins between 1 and the total number of coins, excluding the same number of coins received by any other friend?

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_coins friends additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_coins = 63"
and h1 : "friends = 12"
and h2 : "additional_coins = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..friends}. i) - total_coins"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Alex wants to minimize the number of coins he gives to his friends without giving any two of them the same number of coins. The minimum number of coins he can give to a friend is 1. He then gives 2 coins to another friend, then 3 to another, then 4, and so on, until the last friend receives 12.
 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_coins friends additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_coins = 63"
and h1 : "friends = 12"
and h2 : "additional_coins = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..friends}. i) - total_coins"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 63 total coins that have been divided equally among 12 friends. If each friend gives back a number of coins equal to their position in line (i.e., the first friend gives back one coin, the second friend gives back two coins, and so on), how many additional coins will there be? The final answer is 15.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "friends * (friends + 1) div 2 - coins = 15"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof

 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "friends * (friends + 1) div 2 - coins = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If there are 12 friends and they collectively have 63 coins, find the difference between the sum of the first 12 natural numbers and the total number of coins. The final answer is 15.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "THE x. coins + x \<ge> sum id {1..friends + 1} = 15"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15

 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "THE x. coins + x \<ge> sum id {1..friends + 1} = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Twelve friends have a total of 63 coins. How many more coins do they need so that each of them can have at least 15 coins?

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
and h2 : "sum_friends = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..(friends + 1)}. i)"
and h3 : "additional_coins = h2 - coins"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15

 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
and h2 : "sum_friends = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..(friends + 1)}. i)"
and h3 : "additional_coins = h2 - coins"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 12 friends who have a total of 63 coins. If they want to distribute the coins evenly among themselves and one more friend, how many additional coins do they need? The final answer is 15.

theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "additional_coins = 15 \<and> (\<forall> n. n \<le> friends \<longrightarrow> (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..n}. i) + coins \<ge> (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..(n + 1)}. i))"
a_6.formal solution:

theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
shows  "additional_coins = 15 \<and> (\<forall> n. n \<le> friends \<longrightarrow> (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..n}. i) + coins \<ge> (\<Sum>i \<in> {1..(n + 1)}. i))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There are 12 friends who have a total of 63 coins. They want to make sure that they can divide the coins among them in increasing amounts, starting with one friend getting 1 coin, the next getting 2 coins, and so on. How many additional coins do they need to ensure that they can achieve this goal for all 12 friends? The final answer is 15 additional coins.

assumes h0 : "coins_needed = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..12}. i) - 63"
shows  "coins_needed = 15"

fixes coins_needed :: nat
assumes h0 : "coins_needed = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..12}. i) - 63"

a_8.informal problem: You have a stack of 12 coins, with the first coin having a value of 1, the second coin having a value of 2, and so on, up to the twelfth coin having a value of 12. If the total value of the first 12 coins is 63, how many more coins do you need to reach the desired value? The final answer is 15.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. (\<Sum> i = 1..n. i) \<le> coins + additional_coins \<Longrightarrow> n \<le> friends"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Alex has 12 friends and 63 coins. What is the minimum number of additional coins he needs so that he can give each friend at least one coin and no two friends receive the same number of coins? The final Answer is 15
 ### Proof
 Alex wants to minimize the number of coins he gives to his friends without giving any two of them the same number of coins. The minimum number of coins he can give to a friend is 1. He then gives 2 coins to another friend, then 3 to another, then 4, and so on, until the last friend receives 12.
 The total number of coins Alex has given away is $1+2+3+\cdots+12 = \frac{12 \cdot 13}{2}=78$.
 Thus, Alex needs $78-63=\boxed{15}$ more coins.
 *)

theorem
fixes friends coins additional_coins :: nat
assumes h0 : "friends = 12"
and h1 : "coins = 63"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. (\<Sum> i = 1..n. i) \<le> coins + additional_coins \<Longrightarrow> n \<le> friends"
shows  "additional_coins = 15"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 12 friends who want to split 63 coins among themselves. They decide to distribute the coins in a way that the first friend gets 1 coin, the second friend gets 2 coins, the third friend gets 3 coins, and so on. If they continue this pattern, how many additional coins do they need to ensure that each friend gets at least as many coins as the friend before them? The final answer is 15 additional coins.
